questions.text: During submandibular gland excision, which structure is encountered and divided after retracting the gland inferiorly to expose the deeper portion?
questions.solution:
Submandibular Gland Excision

  • Submandibular gland is mobilized after ligation of the facial vein and artery below the marginal mandibular nerve.
  • The submental artery and vein are ligated to allow access to the deeper structures.
  • Key Steps: Retracting the gland inferiorly exposes the mylohyoid muscle and lingual nerve.
  • The lingual nerve and submandibular ganglion are divided, and Wharton's duct is clamped and ligated.
  • Facial artery is clamped and divided, completing gland excision.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Marginal mandibular nerve is preserved, but it is not divided during the procedure.

Option B) Correct. The lingual nerve is exposed and divided after retracting the gland inferiorly.

Option C) Hypoglossal nerve is visualised but not divided in this procedure.

Option D) Submental artery is ligated earlier during the dissection but is not divided at this stage.

Key Points:

  • Lingual nerve: Divided during submandibular gland excision.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a parotidectomy and needs to identify the facial nerve. Which of the following landmarks is most useful in locating the facial nerve trunk during antegrade dissection?
questions.solution:
Facial Nerve Localization

  • Tragal Pointer (Conley's pointer): Facial nerve lies 1 cm deep and inferior to the tragal cartilage.
  • Digastric Muscle: Facial nerve can be found above the upper border of the posterior belly of this muscle.
  • Tympanomastoid Suture: The nerve lies inferior to this suture line at the stylomastoid foramen.
  • Retrograde Dissection: Used in revision surgeries; buccal branch near the parotid duct is traced proximally to the trunk.

Explanation:

Option A) Correct. The tragal (Conley's) pointer is a key landmark in identifying the facial nerve trunk, lying 1 cm deep and inferior to the tip of the tragal cartilage.

Option B) Incorrect. The sternocleidomastoid muscle is not a primary landmark for facial nerve localization.

Option C) Incorrect. The masseter muscle is involved in jaw movement but is not a landmark for facial nerve identification.

Option D) Incorrect. The mandibular notch is not relevant for identifying the facial nerve trunk.

Key Points:

Tragal pointer and digastric muscle are key landmarks for facial nerve identification in parotidectomy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in the inferior pole of the parotid gland. The swelling has been slowly increasing in size over the past 6 months. The patient has a 40-year history of smoking but denies any pain or facial weakness. On examination, there is a well-defined, firm mass in the inferior pole of the parotid gland without overlying skin changes or tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Warthin's Tumour (Adenolymphoma)

  • Benign tumour of the parotid gland with oncocytic epithelial cells in lymphoid stroma.
  • Epidemiology: Predominantly affects men >60 years, strongly linked to smoking.
  • Location: Mostly in the parotid gland (inferior pole), rarely involves periparotid nodes.
  • Clinical Features: Painless, slow-growing swelling; facial nerve involvement is rare. May present bilaterally.
  • Malignant Transformation: Extremely rare.
  • Histopathology: Cystic and solid areas with lymphoid stroma and papillary projections.
  • Treatment: Complete surgical excision. Recurrence is rare.

Explanation:

Option A) Pleomorphic adenoma: Although a common benign tumour of the parotid gland, pleomorphic adenoma is not typically associated with smoking and usually presents in younger patients. It also lacks the typical cystic features of Warthin's tumour.

Option B) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This malignant salivary gland tumour may present with facial nerve involvement, pain, or rapid growth, which are not seen in this patient.

Option C) Warthin's tumor: Correct. Warthin's tumor is strongly associated with smoking, occurs in the parotid gland, and presents as a painless, slow-growing mass, often seen in older men. It has cystic components and rarely causes facial palsy.

Option D) Acinic cell carcinoma: This is a slow-growing malignant tumor, but it is less common and may involve facial nerve palsy, which is not seen in this case.

Key Points:

Strong association with smoking. Presents as a painless, slowly enlarging mass in older men.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a gradually enlarging, painless swelling in the parotid region. On examination, the mass is well-defined, mobile, and non-tender. There are no signs of facial nerve palsy. Imaging reveals a well-circumscribed mass within the superficial lobe of the parotid gland. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Pleomorphic Adenoma of the Salivary Gland

  • Epidemiology: Most common benign salivary gland tumor, primarily in the parotid gland (>80%), affecting women aged 30-60 years.
  • Clinical Presentation: Painless, slow-growing, well-defined, mobile mass. Rare malignant transformation, presenting as rapid growth or facial nerve palsy.
  • Diagnosis: Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) to differentiate benign from malignant tumors.
  • Histopathology: Mixed epithelial, myoepithelial, and stromal components; oval, spindle-shaped, or plasmacytoid cells.
  • Immunohistochemistry: CK7 (luminal), p63, S-100, SOX10, and SMA (myoepithelial).
  • Management: Surgical excision with a cuff of tissue. Avoid enucleation to prevent capsular rupture and recurrence.
  • Complications: Rare malignant transformation; facial nerve involvement is a red flag.

Explanation:

Option A) Correct. Fine-needle aspiration is the preferred initial diagnostic tool for evaluating salivary gland masses. It helps differentiate benign from malignant lesions, guiding treatment decisions.

Option B) Incorrect. Surgical excision is the definitive treatment, but enucleation is not recommended due to the risk of capsular rupture and recurrence. Excision with a cuff of surrounding tissue is preferred.

Option C) Incorrect. Radiotherapy is not used for benign pleomorphic adenomas.

Option D) Incorrect. Observation is not appropriate for parotid masses as there is a risk of malignant transformation in pleomorphic adenomas.

Key Points:

  • Most Common Benign Salivary Gland Tumor: Pleomorphic adenoma.Preferred Initial Investigation: Fine-needle aspiration (FNA).

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a painless, bluish swelling in the floor of the mouth. The swelling fluctuates in size and sometimes causes difficulty swallowing. Aspiration yields thick, sticky saliva. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ranula

  • A bluish swelling in the floor of the mouth caused by rupture of the sublingual gland’s ducts or acini, resembling the belly of a frog.
  • Types:
  • Simple Ranula: Localized in the floor of the mouth.
  • Plunging Ranula: Extends through the mylohyoid muscle, presenting as a submental swelling.
  • Clinical Features: Soft, fluctuant, painless swelling. May fluctuate in size. Aspiration yields thick, sticky saliva.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis corroborated by imaging such as MRI.

Treatment:

  • Definitive: Sublingual gland excision to prevent recurrence.
  • Alternative: OK-432 injection (not yet widely adopted)
  • Low success rate: Incision, drainage, or marsupialization.

Explanation:

Option A) Incision and drainage are not effective long-term treatments due to the high recurrence rate.

Option B) Correct. Sublingual gland excision is the definitive treatment as ranulas are caused by the rupture of the sublingual gland's ducts. Leaving the gland behind can lead to recurrence.

Option C) Marsupialization has a low success rate and is not the treatment of choice.

Option D) OK-432 injection has been used with some success but requires further evaluation.

Key Points:

Ranulas are caused by the rupture of the sublingual gland's ducts or acini. Sublingual gland excision is the definitive treatment to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with postprandial swelling and pain in the right submandibular region. On examination, a firm mass is palpable in the submandibular duct. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Sialolithiasis

  • The formation of stones (calculi) in the ducts of the salivary glands, most commonly the submandibular gland.
  • Etiology:
    • Chronic dehydration
    • Duct abnormalities
    • Increased calcium content in saliva
  • Clinical Features: Postprandial swelling, pain, asymmetrical gland enlargement.
  • Common Locations:
    • Submandibular gland (85%): Mucinous and viscous saliva, ascending duct.
    • Parotid gland: Distal stones.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Conventional radiographs (80% stones are radio-opaque).
    • CT, MRI sialogram, and ultrasonography for small or non-visible stones.
    • Sialography (gold standard) for diagnosis and therapy.
  • Management:
    • Small stones (<5 mm): Sialendoscopy.
    • Large stones (>5 mm): Duct slitting or ESWL for non-palpable stones.
    • Impacted stones: Transoral approach.
    • Final option: Gland excision if minimally invasive methods fail.

Explanation:

Option A) Correct. Sialendoscopy is the initial diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used for small stones, allowing direct visualization and removal of the stone.

Option B) Transoral duct slitting is reserved for larger (>5 mm) stones or impacted stones.

Option C) Gland excision is considered a last resort if minimally invasive techniques fail.

Option D) ESWL is used for larger, non-palpable stones and stones unsuitable for endoscopic removal.

Key Points:

The submandibular gland is the most common site for sialolithiasis. Sialendoscopy is a minimally invasive technique for small stone removal.

choices.text: Regeneration of parasympathetic fibers to the sweat glands
Incomplete resection of the pleomorphic adenoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoes a superficial parotidectomy for a pleomorphic adenoma. Six months after the surgery, he begins to notice sweating and flushing of the skin overlying his cheek whenever he eats. He is concerned and returns to the clinic for evaluation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Parotid Innervation and Frey's Syndrome

  • Parasympathetic Innervation: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) provides parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland via the otic ganglion and the auriculotemporal nerve.
  • Frey's Syndrome (Gustatory Sweating): Occurs due to aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibers to the sweat glands after injury or surgery (e.g., parotidectomy).
  • Symptoms of Frey's Syndrome: Sweating and flushing over the parotid region when eating.
  • Management: Topical anticholinergics or botulinum toxin injections can be used to alleviate symptoms by inhibiting sweat production.

Explanation:

Option A) Correct. Frey's syndrome, also known as gustatory sweating, is caused by aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibers (which normally innervate the parotid gland) to the sweat glands of the skin overlying the parotid region. This leads to sweating and flushing while eating.

Option B) Incorrect. Sympathetic nerve damage typically leads to loss of sweating (anhidrosis), not gustatory sweating.

Option C) Incorrect. Incomplete resection of a pleomorphic adenoma would more likely result in a recurrence of the tumor, not sweating and flushing over the cheek.

Option D) Incorrect. Infection of the parotid gland would present with pain, swelling, and possible purulent discharge, rather than sweating and flushing during eating.

Key Points:

  • Frey's syndrome involves abnormal reinnervation leading to gustatory sweating after parotidectomy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with a painless, gradually enlarging mass in the parotid region. Biopsy shows mucin-producing and squamoid cells with some intermediate cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma

  • Most common salivary gland malignancy in children and young adults.
  • Peak Incidence: Second decade of life.
  • Common Sites: Parotid gland (most common), minor salivary glands.
  • Risk Factors: Occurs following childhood radiation or chemotherapy.
  • Clinical Presentation: Painless, gradually enlarging soft to firm mass.
  • Histology: Composed of mucin-producing, squamoid, and intermediate cells in varying proportions.
    • Low-grade: Cystic, well circumscribed, rich in mucous cells.
    • High-grade: Solid, infiltrative, nuclear atypia, mitosis, necrosis, perineural invasion, and lymphovascular emboli.
  • Treatment: Complete surgical excision with wide margins; adjuvant radiotherapy for intermediate to high-grade tumours.

Explanation:

Option A) Adenoid cystic carcinoma: A slow-growing, malignant tumor of the salivary glands, characterised by a cribriform ("Swiss cheese") pattern on histology, not typically associated with mucin-producing and squamoid cells.

Option B) Pleomorphic adenoma: The most common benign salivary gland tumor, presenting as a painless, firm, mobile mass. It consists of both epithelial and myoepithelial elements but lacks mucin-producing or squamoid cells.

Option C) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Correct. The most common malignant salivary gland tumor. It is composed of mucin-producing cells, squamous cells, and intermediate cells, making this the most likely diagnosis in this clinical scenario.

Option D) Acinic cell carcinoma: A rare salivary gland tumor often presenting as a slow-growing mass, but it typically shows serous acinar cell differentiation, not mucin-producing cells.

Key Points:

  • Common salivary gland malignancy, particularly affecting children and young adults.

choices.text: Initiate oral antibiotics and discharge home
Needle aspiration of the abscess through the oral cavity
Immediate transcervical drainage under general anesthesia
Incision and drainage via an external cervical approach without imaging

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with neck swelling, difficulty swallowing, fever, and malaise. Physical examination reveals swelling behind the posterior faucial pillar without significant oedema of the soft palate. The child has difficulty breathing, and an MRI confirms the presence of a parapharyngeal abscess What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Parapharyngeal Abscess

  • A deep neck space infection located beside the pharynx, commonly seen in children and often confused with peritonsillar abscess.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Swelling behind the posterior faucial pillar
    • Little or no soft palate oedema
    • Severe malaise, fever, dysphagia, and neck swelling
    • Can compromise both the airway and swallowing
  • Diagnosis: MRI or CT is invaluable to assess the extent of the abscess and plan surgical management.
  • Management:
    • Early cases: IV antibiotics and fluid replacement may resolve the infection.
    • Advanced cases: Transcervical drainage under general anesthesia, especially if the abscess is large or compromises the airway.
    • Oropharyngeal drainage may be attempted if the abscess is pointing into the oropharynx.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Oral antibiotics alone are insufficient. The patient requires hospitalization and IV antibiotics at the very least, but in the presence of a confirmed abscess, drainage is necessary.

Option B) Incorrect. Needle aspiration through the oral cavity could lead to inadequate drainage and risk of airway compromise, especially without appropriate visualization of the extent of the abscess.

Option C) Correct. Parapharyngeal abscesses that compromise airway and swallowing require transcervical drainage under general anesthesia with expertise from a senior anesthetist. This ensures proper drainage while maintaining airway protection.

Option D) Incorrect. Drainage without imaging and proper preparation can result in complications. Imaging like MRI or CT helps guide the surgical approach and ensure complete drainage of the abscess.

Key Points:

Parapharyngeal Abscess: Risk of airway compromise, requiring timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a painless, soft, fluctuant swelling on the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. He has noticed the swelling for the past few months, recently when it became tender and red. Ultrasound suggests a cystic lesion, and fine-needle aspiration yields thick, turbid fluid. The patient has no history of trauma or other systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Branchial Cyst and Branchial Fistula

Branchial Cyst:

  • Origin: Develops from vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • Lining: Squamous epithelium.
  • Contents: Thick, turbid fluid.
  • Presentation: Soft, fluctuant mass located at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, typically in early to middle adulthood. The cyst may transilluminate.
  • Complications: Infection leading to erythema, tenderness, and sometimes difficulty in palpation.
  • Diagnosis: Ultrasound and fine-needle aspiration for confirmation.
  • Treatment: Complete excision, performed when the cyst is quiescent, to prevent recurrence.

Branchial Fistula:

  • Origin: Thought to represent a persistent second branchial cleft.
  • External orifice: Situated in the lower third of the neck near the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • Internal orifice: Located on the anterior aspect of the posterior faucial pillar behind the tonsil.
  • Lining: Ciliated columnar epithelium.
  • Presentation: May present with recurrent mucopurulent discharge onto the neck.
  • Treatment: Complete excision of the tract is required to avoid recurrence.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Necrotic metastatic lymph node: characteristic location suggests a branchial cyst rather than malignancy.

Option B) Branchial cyst: Correct. A branchial cyst typically presents in young to middle-aged adults as a fluctuant mass located at the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It is lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick fluid, often becoming tender if infected.

Option C) Thyroglossal duct cyst: Usually found in the midline of the neck and moves with swallowing or protrusion of the tongue, which is not described in this case.

Option D) Cervical lymphadenitis: This typically presents with more systemic symptoms, such as fever and tenderness, and is associated with infective causes.

Key Points:

  • Branchial cyst is a common congenital neck mass in adults, often located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • Branchial fistula presents with a persistent tract lined by ciliated epithelium and can be associated with recurrent infections or discharge.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with a soft, compressible, translucent swelling on the left side of the neck, which increases in size when the infant cries. The swelling transilluminates brilliantly on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cystic Hygroma

  • A congenital malformation of the lymphatic system, presenting as a cystic, fluid-filled mass lined by a single layer of epithelium.
  • Common Sites: Most often in the neck (75% of cases), but can also be seen in the axilla, mediastinum, groin, and cheek.
  • Presentation: Soft, compressible, brilliantly transilluminant swelling, often increasing in size when the child coughs or cries.
  • Complications: May cause airway obstruction if large or involve critical areas like the tongue or submandibular region.
  • Diagnosis: Primarily clinical, confirmed by ultrasound or MRI to determine the extent of the lesion.
  • Management:
    • Observation: Small, asymptomatic lesions.
    • Surgical excision: If symptomatic or enlarging.
    • Sclerotherapy: Used in certain cases to shrink the cystic structure.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Thyroglossal cyst typically presents as a midline neck swelling that moves with swallowing or protrusion of the tongue.

Option B) Cystic hygroma is characterized by a soft, compressible swelling that is brilliantly transilluminant, commonly seen in the neck. It is the most likely diagnosis given the clinical presentation.

Option C) Branchial cleft cyst is a lateral neck swelling but does not transilluminate brilliantly and is typically firmer.

Option D) Dermoid cyst is a midline or lateral neck swelling that contains sebaceous material and is non-transilluminant.

Key Points:

Cystic hygroma presents as a brilliantly transilluminant swelling. The most common site is the neck.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man from a high-altitude region presents with a slowly enlarging, painless lump on the side of his neck. On examination, the mass is firm, rubbery, and pulsatile, located at the carotid bifurcation. It moves side to side but not up and down. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Paraganglioma (Carotid Body Tumour)

  • Rare tumour arising from chemoreceptor cells, often associated with high-altitude living due to chronic hypoxia.
  • Etiology: Linked to mutations in the SDH enzyme; familial cases are associated with pheochromocytoma.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Slow-growing, painless mass at the carotid bifurcation.
    • Firm, rubbery, pulsatile, and mobile from side to side..
  • Investigations:
    • Carotid angiogram: Demonstrates splaying of the carotid bifurcation and tumour blush.
    • MRI: Provides detailed imaging.
    • FNA/biopsy: Contraindicated due to the risk of vascular injury.
  • Shamblin Classification: Determines the resectability of the tumour
    • Type I: Localised to less than 180° of carotid vessel.
    • Type II: Surrounds over 180° of the vessel.
    • Type III: Completely encases the vessels, requiring more complex resection.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgery is considered carefully due to the risks, especially in elderly patients.
    • Radiotherapy can be used to prevent further growth but is not curative.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is contraindicated in suspected paraganglioma due to the risk of vascular injury.

Option B) Incorrect. Biopsy is not recommended for these tumours as it can cause significant complications.

Option C) Correct. Carotid angiogram is the diagnostic tool of choice to demonstrate tumour vascularity and splaying of the carotid bifurcation.

Option D) Incorrect. Radiotherapy may prevent tumour growth but is not the first-line approach in diagnosing this tumour.

Key Points:

Paragangliomas are rare and typically benign but can cause complications due to their vascularity.A carotid angiogram is the diagnostic test of choice.

choices.text: Free flaps rely on the recipient site's blood supply for survival
The fibula is the most commonly used soft-tissue free flap in oral reconstruction
The radial forearm free flap (RFFF) is commonly used for both soft-tissue and bone replacement
Chimeric flaps are not used in complex reconstructions

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents for reconstruction following the resection of a large oral cavity tumor. The surgical team decides to perform a free flap reconstruction to replace both bone and soft tissue. Which of the following is true regarding free flaps in oral cavity reconstruction?
questions.solution:
Free Flaps in Oral Cavity Reconstruction

  • Free flaps are vascularized tissues harvested from a donor site, transferred to a recipient site, and anastomosed to local vessels to provide independent blood supply.
  • Soft-Tissue Flaps: Common soft-tissue free flaps used in oral cavity reconstruction include:
    • Radial Forearm Free Flap (RFFF)
    • Anterolateral Thigh (ALT) Flap
    • Rectus Abdominis Flap
    • Latissimus Dorsi Flap
  • Composite Flaps: Bone-containing (composite) flaps, such as the fibula, iliac crest (DCIA), and scapula, are used to reconstruct both bone and soft tissues.
  • Chimeric Flaps: These flaps involve multiple tissue types (e.g., bone and muscle) with independently mobile components, commonly used for complex reconstructions like the thoracodorsal system.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Free flaps are vascularized tissues that have their own independent blood supply through anastomosis of the artery and vein to local vessels, and they do not rely on the recipient site for blood supply.

Option B) Incorrect. The fibula is the most commonly used bone-containing (composite) flap, not soft tissue, for oral cavity reconstruction.

Option C) Correct. The radial forearm free flap (RFFF) is a versatile flap used for both soft tissue and bone replacement in oral cavity reconstruction.

Option D) Incorrect. Chimeric flaps, which contain multiple tissue types (e.g., osseous and soft tissue) that are independently mobile, are used for complex reconstructions.

Key Points:

Free Flaps: Used in reconstruction, especially after oncologic resections, with their own vascular supply.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a white patch on the lateral border of her tongue. The lesion has been present for 6 months and measures 250 mm². She is a non-smoker. Which of the following features increases the risk of malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
Premalignant Lesions of the Oral Cavity

  • Common Premalignant Lesions: Leukoplakia, erythroplakia, erythroleukoplakia, proliferative verrucous leukoplakia (PVL), oral submucous fibrosis, oral lichen planus, and lupus erythematosus.
  • Leukoplakia: White patch or plaque that cannot be rubbed off or clinically/pathologically classified.
  • Erythroplakia: Bright red, velvety plaque with a higher risk of malignant transformation.
  • Speckled Leukoplakia (Erythroleukoplakia): Combination of white and red lesions; carries the highest risk of malignant transformation.
  • Biopsy: Essential for diagnosis and assessment of dysplasia (mild, moderate, severe).

Risk Factors for Malignant Transformation:

  • Female sex
  • Lesions >200 mm²
  • Non-homogeneous lesions
  • Non-smokers
  • Multiple lesions
  • Location on lateral border of tongue or floor of mouth

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Female sex is associated with a higher risk of malignant transformation.

Option B) Incorrect. Larger lesions (>200 mm²) have a greater risk of malignant change.

Option C) Correct. Non-homogeneous lesions are more likely to undergo malignant transformation.

Option D) Incorrect. Non-smokers with these lesions may have an increased risk of malignancy.

Key Points:

Erythroleukoplakia has the highest risk of malignant transformation. Risk factors include size, non-homogeneity, and lesion location.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered a major risk factor for oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Risk Factors for Oral Cavity Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Major Risk Factors:

  • Tobacco Use: Strong dose-response relationship.
  • Alcohol Consumption: Particularly when combined with tobacco.
  • Betel Quid (Areca Nut): A leading cause in South Asian populations.
  • HPV Infection: Accounts for a small percentage (~5%) of OCSCCs.
  • Hereditary Conditions: Fanconi anaemia, Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
  • Immunosuppression: Increases risk due to reduced immune surveillance.
  • Chronic Infections: Associated with long-standing inflammation and irritation.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Tobacco use is a well-known risk factor for OCSCC.

Option B) Incorrect. Alcohol consumption increases the risk of OCSCC, especially in combination with tobacco.

Option C) Incorrect. HPV infection accounts for a small percentage (around 5%) of OCSCCs, primarily contributing to oropharyngeal cancers.

Option D) Correct. EBV infection is primarily associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not OCSCC.

Key Points:

  • Tobacco, alcohol, and betel quid are major risk factors.
  • HPV is a minor risk factor in OCSCC but major in oropharyngeal cancers.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a 3 cm tumour in the oral cavity, with a depth of invasion (DOI) of 8 mm. According to the AJCC, what is the correct T stage of this tumour?
questions.solution:
T1: Tumour ≤2 cm with DOI ≤5 mm.

T2: Tumour ≤2 cm with DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm or tumour >2 cm but ≤4 cm with DOI ≤10 mm.

T3: Tumour >4 cm or any tumour with DOI >10 mm.

T4a: Moderately advanced local disease (invasion through cortical bone, skin, or adjacent structures).

Key Points:

  • Depth of invasion (DOI) is critical for T-stage determination.
